image.altText: Middle aged man in suit, flanked by reporter, ABC microphone in foreground

items.synopsis: Lawyers for Tim Mathieson, the former partner of Julia Gillard, say he will plead guilty to a charge of sexual assault during a hearing in the Melbourne Magistrates' Court.

title.children: Tim Mathieson, former partner of Julia Gillard, to plead guilty to sexual assault charge

image.altText: Shooting scene

items.synopsis: Police say a fatal shooting in Canterbury early this morning is believed to be a targeted incident. It comes less than 24 hours after a separate incident where a lawyer was shot.

title.children: Police probe 'common link' between recent Sydney shootings after man gunned down in city's south-west

image.altText: Kirrawee nursing home Joan Hobbs

items.synopsis: The family of Joan Hobbs have called for better staffing after the 89-year-old woman was attacked by a fellow dementia patient with a walking frame.

title.children: Elderly woman allegedly bashed to death by fellow dementia patient in Sydney nursing home

image.altText: Image of couple in front of cancelled and sign and Metricon label

items.synopsis: Metricon, the biggest home builder in the country, has told some customers to pay painfully higher prices or risk losing their new homes and deposits in a contract nightmare affecting home owners.

title.children: Building giant tells buyers to pay hundreds of thousands extra or lose homes and deposits

image.altText: A young blonde girl smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: Tasmania Police have arrested a 36-year-old man over the disappearance of teenager Shyanne-Lee Tatnell and have confirmed remains found yesterday at a rural property are human.

title.children: Tasmania Police arrest man over Shyanne-Lee Tatnell's disappearance, confirm remains found are human

image.altText: Greg Jenkins 1

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank is hiking interest rates — and hitting borrowers — to fight high inflation, but data suggests the fight is being undermined by big-spending baby boomers.

title.children: 'We're not paying the price': The boomers boosting inflation as the RBA lifts rates to fight it

image.altText: a woman looking left

items.synopsis: The police minister says detectives are working around the clock to investigate a series of shootings this week, as the NSW opposition claims the government has "lost control" of the streets.

title.children: 'Lost control' of crime in Sydney: Spate of shootings puts pressure on NSW government

image.altText: a man talking

items.synopsis: The regulator argued the 8-point font on the former MP's election posters were too small to read from a distance.

title.children: 'This case was a disgrace from the start': Craig Kelly wins court battle over font size on his election posters

image.altText: A new underground metro railway line will be built between Parramatta and the Sydney CBD.

items.synopsis: It was billed as Australia's biggest public transport project but is the promise of four metro lines for Sydney just a pipe dream? Here's how the project began, the hurdles it's faced and where it's up to now.

title.children: Sydney's metro mayhem — what's gone wrong?

image.altText: A composite image of Sinead O'Conner and Prince

items.synopsis: Despite being Sinéad O'Connor's most recognisable song, Nothing Compares 2 U originally came from the pen of Prince.

title.children: Nothing Compares 2 U: How the song of 1990 went from Prince to Sinéad and back again

image.altText: Sinead O'connor wearing a priests black outfit with a cross holding a microphone and smiling

items.synopsis: Irish singer-songwriter Sinéad O'Connor, who became a superstar in her mid-20s, dies at 56.

title.children: Sinéad O'Connor, who topped charts in the 90s, dies aged 56

image.altText: Chris Hipkins and Anthony Albanese standing at podiums at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese insists Australia's ties with New Zealand will not suffer if there is a change of government in Wellington, as the man firming to replace incumbent Chris Hipkins talks up his relationship with Australia's prime minister.

title.children: As Albanese tours NZ with PM Hipkins, he takes a brief aside with nation's next possible leader

image.altText: A Dutch player dribbles the ball as she is challenged by a USA opponent at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: The USA and Netherlands finish deadlocked at 1-1 across the Tasman, as Australia prepares to cheer on the Matildas in their next group match against Nigeria this evening. Follow live.

title.children: USA, Netherlands play out tense World Cup draw, Matildas prepare for tonight's match

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It was a dramatic group-stage match, and it has ended in a draw. After all that, the US will be more disappointed not to get the win, as they were so dominant after getting that equaliser. They looked unstoppable once they had their full array of attacking talent going full throttle, so well done to the Dutch for holding out. Still, I think it has shown some chinks in the US armour, as they looked pretty rattled for much of that first half and some of the second. Rose Lavelle, who I maintain is the best player to watch in the world, added the dynamism the US needed in the second half. I expect she'll start for them in the next game.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FULL-TIME: USA 1 - 1 Netherlands

children.content: (Getty)
It was a dramatic group-stage match, and it has ended in a draw. After all that, the US will be more disappointed not to get the win, as they were so dominant after getting that equaliser.
They looked unstoppable once they had their full array of attacking talent going full throttle, so well done to the Dutch for holding out.
Still, I think it has shown some chinks in the US armour, as they looked pretty rattled for much of that first half and some of the second.
Rose Lavelle, who I maintain is the best player to watch in the world, added the dynamism the US needed in the second half. I expect she'll start for them in the next game.
(PressBox)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: My prediction is Australia 2 - 0 Nigeria. Goals from Raso and Gorry. You heard it here first.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Predictions time: Who's scoring the goals tonight?

children.content: My prediction is Australia 2 - 0 Nigeria.
Goals from Raso and Gorry.
You heard it here first.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just as Van de Donk seemed to rile her up, Lindsey Horan does brilliantly from the corner, angling her run to the near post and heading home with power. It's 1-1! Really great header when you see it on replay, diverted with venom into the top corner.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 62' HORAN scores for USA! It's 1-1

children.content: Just as Van de Donk seemed to rile her up, Lindsey Horan does brilliantly from the corner, angling her run to the near post and heading home with power.
Really great header when you see it on replay, diverted with venom into the top corner.
(Getty)

image.altText: Bald man in army greens holding a gun in front of white wall.

items.synopsis: One of the top leaders in the Russian Army, Sergei Surovikin, has not been seen since the mutiny against the Kremlin last month. At first it seems odd, but it turns out General Surovikin is not who he seems.

title.children: Russian 'General Armageddon' Sergei Surovikin is missing — is he 'resting' or Resting In Peace?

image.altText: A composite image of Emmanuel Macron holding two clenched fists and Antony Blinken looking stoic

items.synopsis: The United States says "the door is open" for New Zealand to join AUKUS, as three of the world's most influential leaders continue their tour of the Pacific region.

title.children: Macron takes a swipe at China warning of 'new imperialism' in the Pacific as Blinken opens the door to AUKUS

image.altText: A composite image of Kevin Spacey clutching an Oscar and a court sketch

items.synopsis: The trial against Kevin Spacey was a strange mix of celebrity witnesses, tearful testimony and graphic allegations of sexual violence. WARNING: Some readers may find details in this story distressing.

title.children: Kevin Spacey was one of the biggest names hit by #MeToo. Here's why a London court cleared him

image.altText: Young man stands facing away from camera wearing a hat

items.synopsis: A children's magistrate in Port Kembla has described this innovative mentoring program as "remarkable" and "transformative" for young people who were once on a bleak path. But its future is under threat.

title.children: This 'extraordinary' program halting domestic violence in its tracks is about to run out of money

image.altText: Composite image of football fans from the 32 nations competing at the FIFA Women's World Cup

items.synopsis: With the FIFA Women's World Cup in full swing, fans all around Australia show their true colours and share their passion for the world game, and their country.

title.children: Here's what it means to football fans from all over the world to see a Women's World Cup here

image.altText: A woman in a green top stands against a stone wall.

items.synopsis: Sarab was 11 when ISIS militants attacked her village and sold her into slavery. Five years later, she had been given to six different men. Now, she wants justice, writes Stephanie March.

title.children: Abducted and sold into slavery at 11, now Sarab wants justice

image.altText: A couple in their backyard.

items.synopsis: Although it's been in planning for more than 20 years, a dozen families on the Sunshine Coast are reeling after the shock discovery that their homes will be acquired for a major new road and rail project, the Mooloolah River Interchange.

title.children: Residents shocked by 'railway through our back patio' as homes to be bulldozed for transport corridor

image.altText: A man points to a shrub on fire, with a crowd of onlookers listening.

items.synopsis: Insurance, approvals, and understanding within government have been hampering efforts to ramp up cultural burning, but a large volume of requests from private landholders is forcing the issue.

title.children: Push to reduce red tape to allow for more cultural burning being considered in NSW

image.altText: A holding pen crammed with goats on a clear, sunny day.

items.synopsis: China is stocking up on Australian goat meat, which is now selling for less than $3 a kilogram — down from $9 a year ago. But that's not all farmers are frustrated about.

title.children: China hungry for cheap Australian goat meat, but oversupply leaves sour taste for farmers

image.altText: A woman in a brown apron stands frowning behind a counter in a cafe with a coffee machine.

items.synopsis: The revamp of a street in Orange was designed to attract more people to the precinct. Instead, it has left a cafe owner taking a significant financial hit and fielding daily complaints.

title.children: Plans to revitalise NSW city centre turn into 'hot mess' as businesses go backwards

image.altText: Laughing woman, long black hair, eyes shut, head thrown back, seated at kitchen table with laughing grey-haired ma, white shirt.

items.synopsis: This shire has the highest percentage of organ and tissue donors registered in NSW. Could its sense of community and "giving nature" be a contributing factor?

title.children: Northern NSW hamlet tops state for organ and tissue donor rates

image.altText: The view over nepal from a paraglider.

items.synopsis: Two New South Wales men have become the first people to legally paraglide from a 5,200-metre peak in the Everest region of Nepal, capturing spectacular footage for a charity film.

title.children: Aussie paragliders achieve world first with 5,200m-high launch from Nepalese mountains

image.altText: Two Australian female swimmers stand on the medal podium at the World Aquatics Championships.

items.synopsis: At just 19, Mollie O'Callaghan writes herself into the record books at the World Aquatics Championships in Fukuoka, winning gold ahead of Australian teammate Ariarne Titmus in the women's 200 metres freestyle.

title.children: Aussie O'Callaghan stunned after breaking long-standing swimming world record

image.altText: John Woodman sits in a chair in front of a microphone against a wooden wall as he testifies at the IBAC hearing in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: Property developer John Woodman plied suburban councillors with hundreds of thousands of dollars in exchange for support of his lucrative projects, a damning report from Victoria's anti-corruption watchdog has found.

title.children: Developer offered councillors cash for support, anti-corruption report finds

image.altText: Jerome Powell stands at a podium behind a wall of American flags.

items.synopsis: The ASX has set a 100-day high as the market continues to digest yesterday's better-than-expected inflation numbers, while in the US, stocks finished flat as the Federal Reserve hikes interest rates to a 22-year high. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX at five-month high, Fed raises rates as expected, EY staff bullied and overworked

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As you've been hearing wholesale prices are down 60 per cent on last year amid lower commodity prices and more supply generated by coal, wind and solar. But consumers have faced big price rises on their electricity bills. The Grattan Institute's Alison Reeve told Ros Childs on the ABC News Channel that it will be some time before consumers see an improvement in their bills.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Power prices rise despite fall in wholesale costs

children.content: As you've been hearing wholesale prices are down 60 per cent on last year amid lower commodity prices and more supply generated by coal, wind and solar.
But consumers have faced big price rises on their electricity bills.
The Grattan Institute's Alison Reeve told Ros Childs on the ABC News Channel that it will be some time before consumers see an improvement in their bills.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: EY boss David Larocca has promised to implement the report's 27 recommendations. These include: Revision of key performance indicators to strengthen leadership and recognise contributions to improving diversity, equity and inclusion Increase accountability of staff retention by charging the costs of excessive turnover to service lines Reduce overwork and excessive hours through more accurate project scoping, resourcing and costing EY is also trialing five pilot initiatives including more time in lieu and margin relief to assess partners on revenue measures, but not profit margin. Staff who experienced bullying, racism or sexual harassment over the last five years were less likely to have confidence in making a report or a complaint. "Many people have experienced retribution, particularly loss of access to advancement opportunities, when they have either formally or informally reported harmful experiences," the report found. Women were more likely to experience sexual harassment than men, and people who identified as Indian, Chinese, Maori, Hindu and Muslim were more likely to face racism. The report comes as the big four accounting firms face an existential crisis after Pwc leaked confidential government tax plans to help their multinational clients pay less tax. They face being excluded from lucrative government contracts and there are calls for a royal commission into the consulting industry.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EY accepts report's 27 recommendations

children.content: EY boss David Larocca has promised to implement the report's 27 recommendations.
These include:
Revision of key performance indicators to strengthen leadership and recognise contributions to improving diversity, equity and inclusion
Increase accountability of staff retention by charging the costs of excessive turnover to service lines
Reduce overwork and excessive hours through more accurate project scoping, resourcing and costing
EY is also trialing five pilot initiatives including more time in lieu and margin relief to assess partners on revenue measures, but not profit margin.
Staff who experienced bullying, racism or sexual harassment over the last five years were less likely to have confidence in making a report or a complaint.
"Many people have experienced retribution, particularly loss of access to advancement opportunities, when they have either formally or informally reported harmful experiences," the report found.
Women were more likely to experience sexual harassment than men, and people who identified as Indian, Chinese, Maori, Hindu and Muslim were more likely to face racism.
The report comes as the big four accounting firms face an existential crisis after Pwc leaked confidential government tax plans to help their multinational clients pay less tax.
They face being excluded from lucrative government contracts and there are calls for a royal commission into the consulting industry.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The EY review was commissioned in September 2022 following the death of auditor Aishwarya Venkat in the firm's Sydney office. More than 4,500 current and former employees were surveyed across Australia and New Zealand. EY says it has already put in place measures to support well being and workplace culture including mental health first aid staff and welfare contact officers. The report found that many of the problems identified are known challenges across professional services firms in Australia, particularly overwork. EY Oceania chief executive David Larocca says the firm has fallen short of the standard that everyone who works at EY has a right to expect. “There are findings in the report that are distressing and completely unacceptable. Bullying, sexual harassment and racism have no place at EY Oceania and I apologise to anyone who has suffered as a result.” " The impact of long working hours is also significant and taking a heavy toll on the well being of many of our people.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EY boss says report findings are 'distressing and completely unacceptable'

children.content: The EY review was commissioned in September 2022 following the death of auditor Aishwarya Venkat in the firm's Sydney office.
More than 4,500 current and former employees were surveyed across Australia and New Zealand.
EY says it has already put in place measures to support well being and workplace culture including mental health first aid staff and welfare contact officers.
The report found that many of the problems identified are known challenges across professional services firms in Australia, particularly overwork.
EY Oceania chief executive David Larocca says the firm has fallen short of the standard that everyone who works at EY has a right to expect.

“There are findings in the report that are distressing and completely unacceptable. Bullying, sexual harassment and racism have no place at EY Oceania and I apologise to anyone who has suffered as a result.”
" The impact of long working hours is also significant and taking a heavy toll on the well being of many of our people.”

image.altText: Photograph outside the Australian Tax Office headquarters

items.synopsis: The Australian Tax Office privately settled with PwC over an undisclosed matter in March, as the firm contended with a confidentiality breach within its ranks.

title.children: PwC reveals private settlement over undisclosed matter with Tax Office, as it contended with unfolding tax leak saga

image.altText: An african man sitting infront of a white table and microphone with nine men in military uniforms behind him

items.synopsis: Colonel Amadou Abdramane appears in a video saying Niger's defence forces are putting an end to President Mohamed Bazoum's regime.

title.children: Niger soldiers remove president, seize power in coup
